Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Parental care and the integration of personality and plasticity at multiple levels of phenotypic variance
Award.AbstractNarration: Labile traits like behavior exhibit variation at multiple levels of organization; within individuals, among individuals, and among populations and species. The nature of this variation influences evolutionary processes, and can help explain how organisms respond to rapid environmental changes and why some thrive in new habitats and others dwindle. In this project, variance in parental behavior of house sparrows will be measured across multiple breeding attempts and separated into its constituent components. Manipulations of offspring demand will test among two alternative hypotheses for why individuals that routinely assiduously care for offspring also are more flexible. A novel statistical technique will be used to assess hierarchical patterns of variance in parental behavior. Additional experiments using controlled feeders in both free-living and captive subjects will test if differences in within-individual variance in care are a byproduct of decisions affecting mean levels of care or adaptive management of random variance in available food. Finally, measurements of hormone levels in response to manipulations as well as a novel experiment in which two hormones will be manipulated will test between alternative hypotheses about the underlying mechanisms that influence phenotypic variance in parental behavior at multiple levels. The project will train a post-doctoral scholar, support graduate research projects, foster undergraduates to gain experience in blending biology and statistics, and help support several initiatives to provide new opportunities for experiencing research to those without access to active scientific studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parental care occurs in many different kinds of organisms, and it varies in type and degree among species, among individuals within species, and within individuals. The latter fact tells us that parental care is flexible. Parents of many organisms adjust their care to prevailing conditions in apparently adaptive ways. This collaborative project focused on seeking a deeper understanding of the nature of this flexibility, in particular that which occurs in the face of unpredictable variation, using breeding house sparrows as the study system. We first asked whether parents might differ in their ability to assess changes occurring around them. One major change that parent sparrows respond to variably is the shifting demand of the offspring as they get older. Two undergraduate students designed and carried out an experiment that manipulated the cues of offspring age. They discovered that parents quickly adjusted to age even if it the change seems unnatural, such as when offspring suddenly got younger. In this context, they were more flexible than predicted. However, when we altered the number of offspring, their adjustment depended on both the prevailing environment and if the number was increased or decreased. Thus their flexibility was constrained by other environmental factors. We manipulated hormones thought to affect parental behavior and measured parent foraging and provisioning behavior in captivity. Simple effects of hormones could be ruled out, but complex interactions remain a possibility. We also asked if the variability in food supply itself can be assessed by parents and then either avoided or preferred. We found that individuals differ in their expression of this variance, but whether this is a byproduct or something that parents actively manage is not yet clear. 

This project demanded development of new statistical tools to analyze complex data and stimulated collaboration between biologists and statisticians. We generated software to analyze hierarchical variance in both means and residual variances and the application of this to several datasets have been published. The new tools will be of value to researchers studying other kinds of traits in other organisms, and so have general value. Project personnel also linked with other researchers to develop simulation software designed to help study the strengths and weaknesses of these techniques and to teach them to others. Teaching these tools to new researchers occurred in several venues around the world.

The project provided training in field and aviary research and statistical analysis to students at a variety of levels, from advanced (post-doctoral) to beginning. Many have now gone on to further training, and some have published the results of their studies. Data collected as part of the project and already published have been archived in public forums. We are also combining unpublished data with those of other researchers to pursue new questions about the nature of parental behavior.
